abstract.text: A glyph attribute in an attributed string.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Glyphs are the graphic representations of characters, stored in a font, that the text system draws on a display or printed page. Before text can be laid out, the layout manager (<
) generates a stream of glyphs, using the character and font information specified by the attributed string and contained in the font file.
) and provides a means to override the standard glyph generation process and substitute a specified glyph over the attribute’s range.
Glyph attributes are integer values that the layout manager uses to denote special handling for particular glyphs during rendering.

enables you to override a font’s built-in mapping from a Unicode character code to a corresponding glyph ID. Overriding the mapping allows you to specify a variant glyph for a given character if the font contains multiple variations for that character or to specify a glyph that doesn’t have a standard mapping (such as some ligature glyphs).

abstract.text: Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your macOS app.
Values that map character identifiers to glyphs.
The font rendering mode.
The type used to specify glyphs.
An object that performs the initial, nominal glyph generation phase in the layout process.
A glyph attribute in an attributed string.
The string containing the character represented by the glyph.
A value specifying the glyph–to–character identifier mapping of the receiver.
The receiver’s character identifier (CID).
The glyph identifier, specified as the index into the internal glyph table of the font.
The receiver’s glyph name.
Creates a glyph info object from the specified glyph identifier and font informaton.
Instantiates and returns an
object using a character identifier and a character collection.
Instantiates and returns a glyph information object using a glyph index and a specified font.
Instantiates and returns a glyph information object using a glyph name and a specified font.
The name of a glyph info object.
A set of methods that a glyph storage object must implement to interact properly with
An object that coordinates the layout and display of text characters.
These constants define reserved glyph codes.
A string of text that manages data, layout, and stylistic information for ranges of characters to support rendering.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
